Comment: I always like to play 1. d4 because it gives you a range of opening ideas.
1. d4 c6 - I do not know this opening. However, it is most likely that 2. ... d5 will be played.
e4 dominates the centre.
Black replies 2. ... d5, just as predicted.
If 3. exd5 cxd5, we have a normal 1. d4 d5 opening, save that my e- file is vulnerable to attack, and black's c-file is half-open. Thus, I proceed with 3. e5.
This move is by far a mistake. The queen should not go out in the opening unless the opponent is sure: however, the more important reason is that the queen will be vulnerable to attack.
The queen is now chased away by Bd2. Nc3 would have been possible, as would 4. c3, but the bishop has a better taste.
The only available square save c7 and d8. This threatens 5. ... Qxb2 or 5. ... Qxd4, the latter better.
Nf3 to defend the d-pawn, a key pawn. Note that after 5. ... Qxb2, there is now sufficient attack for white.
5. ... e6 etches in the light-squared bishop, but the other bishop can come out also. It also supports the d-pawn.
6. a4!? A most obvious thought, is 7. a5 next move. But 7. a5 has also more sophistication than you may think ...
Black ignores the threat completely, and instead develops his knight.
7. a5!  There are only 3 squares that Black can escape with the queen.
The title tells the story. This is by far the worst move in Black's play, as you will see soon. Let's play 'spot the move' ...
8. Bc3! And within only eight moves of the game, black's queen is trapped.
The only beneficial gain, but then Black will be three points down.
To develop the LSB to b7. However, after the pawn exchange, Black has axb6, threatening the bishop, or Nxc6, developing the knight.
To develop the LSB to b7. However, after the pawn exchange, Black has axb6, threatening the bishop, or Nxc6, developing the knight.
This prevents Bb7. However, after b5!, the pawn is trapped.
b5! and now the pawn is unfortunately etched in.
Nd2, preparing c4! next move, collapsing the black pawn structure.
